TA 9052-BAN: Dhaka Metro Project 
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The Government of Bangladesh intends to improve the public transport system in Dhaka 
by constructing additional metro lines. This project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will 
assess the findings of the Revised Strategic Transport Plan (RSTP) for Dhaka and recommend 
and prepare a priority metro project for investment by ADB. The RSTP is expected to be 
completed in 2015. The PPTA will prepare pre-feasibility studies including cost-benefit analysis 
to decide on the priority interventions in consultation with the government and define the scope 
for detailed design to be prepared under the proposed TA loan, scheduled for approval in 2017. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table A3.1.  
 
Table A3.1: Summary of Major Outputs and Activities 
Expected  Expected 
Major Activities  Completion Date  Major Outputs  Completion Date 
Operations Plan and network  November 2016  Inception Report  August 2016 
Feasibility Study  April 2017  Interim Report  December 2016 
Economic/Financial Analysis  June 2017  Draft Final Report  June 2017 
Institutional Assessment  December 2016  Final Report  October 2017 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The technical assistance (TA) is estimated to cost $1.5 million equivalent, of which $1.3 
million equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-V). The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
provision  of  office  space,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  detailed  cost  estimate  is 
presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  An international consulting firm will be recruited by ADB using the quality and cost-based 
selection method with full technical proposal and a quality to cost ratio of 90:10 due to the 
specialized technical requirements and the nature of this project as a multidisciplinary metro 
project. The consultants will be selected in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The consulting contract will be an output-
based contract with lump-sum out-of-pocket expenses. The Communications Expert will be 
recruited as an individual consultant. 
 
5.  The PPTA will be carried out in two phases: (i) in the first phase, the consultant will 
select the most appropriate corridor for metro development by ADB based on the findings of the 
RSTP and consultations with stakeholders and the government; (ii) in the second phase, the 
PPTA will prepare the pre-feasibility study for the selected corridor, carry out the related surveys 
and studies and define the scope for the detailed design to be carried out under the proposed 
TA loan.

6.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants of the consulting team are 
described  in  paragraphs  7  to  13;  the  tasks  for  the  individual  communications  expert  are 
summarized in paragraph 14.  
 
7.  Urban Transport Planner/Team Leader (international, 8 person-months); Transport 
Planner/Deputy  Team  Leader  (national,  12  person-months);  Metro  Operations  Expert 
(international, 2 person-months); Road  and  Bridge  Engineer (national, 6 person-months); 
Alignment  Expert  (international,  3  person-months);  Urban  Planner  (national,  3  person-
months); Rolling Stock Expert (international, 3 person-months; national, 3 person-months); 
and Systems Engineer (international, 3 person-months): Review the RSTP and other available 
master  plans,  data  and  studies,  based  on  the  future  long-term  plan  for  the  Dhaka  Metro 
network, identify priorities for ADB’s investment, study alternatives and conduct the necessary 
surveys; propose improvements in integrating transport modes in physical, operational and 
commercial ways; assess the impact of the project on land-use planning and the targeted urban 
development in Dhaka; study the location of stations and depots with respect to the availability 
of land and access as well as expected origins and destinations of passengers; assess the 
technical  feasibility  of  the  proposed  metro  line  based  on  inputs  from  financial,  social, 
resettlement and environmental studies, recommend a preferred alignment for further study;

3   
conduct a preliminary geometric design; prepare the Bill of Quantities (BOQ) and cost estimate 
within a 15% margin of error; investigate availability and costs of construction materials and 
equipment; develop a design standard considering the ongoing JICA-financed project; prepare 
technical specifications for all railway components such as rolling stock, track, signal, telecom 
and interlocking system, structure gauges etc.; identify areas for private sector involvement, e.g. 
in the station development and public-private partnerships; study options for the organizational 
and institutional set-up of the Metro company for the operation phase considering cost-recovery 
strategies  and  the  involvement  of  the  public  sector;  Identify  institutional  and  financial 
requirements for maintaining sustainability of the metro operations; prepare documents for ADB 
to process the loan; prepare an action plan for institutional development. 
 
8.  Procurement  Expert  (national,  3  person-months):  Suggest  contract  packaging  and 
implementation  arrangements;  prepare  master  bid  documents  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
standard bid documents and procurement guidelines; recommend a bid evaluation procedure, 
prepare executing agency procurement capacity assessment, and suggest remedial action plan 
to build capacity to minimize procurement and financial management risks; propose indicative 
loan related procurement plan with suggested level of post review based on executing agency 
capacity assessment; and indicative implementation schedule with proposed sequencing of 
consultant recruitment, procurement and most importantly project implementation. 
 
9.  Transport Economist (international, 2 person-months); Traffic Modeler (national, 3 
person-months);  and  Financial  Management  Expert  (national,  2  person-months):  Review 
RSTP, existing traffic data and studies for the project area, plan and carry out necessary traffic 
counts, origin-destination surveys and interviews; and forecast traffic demand over a 20-year 
period.  The  economist  will  undertake  economic  analysis  of  the  project,  following  ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.  The  Financial  Management  expert  will 
undertake (i) a governance (financial management, institution) appraisal for the Dhaka Metro 
Corporation and fiscal assessment of the Ministry of Road Transport and Bridges, (ii) support 
the preparation and agreement of cost estimates and a financing plan; (iii) prepare fund flow 
arrangements  and  schemes  considering  ADB’s  disbursement  procedures;  and  (iv)  prepare 
financial projections and conduct financial analyses of Dhaka Mass Transit Company and the 
Ministry of Road Transport and Bridges, and incremental recurrent costs, to determine financial 
sustainability,  and  review  proposed  tariff  policies.  Based  on  the  assessment,  the  financial 
management expert will recommend measures to strengthen specific areas. 
 
10.  Power Sector Expert (national, 3 person-months): Together with Rolling Stock Experts 
and System Engineer, recommend the most suitable power supply system and locations for 
substations  and feeding  lines from  the  national grid,  considering reliability  and  emergency 
operation based on the traffic forecast prepared and the options for future extensions of the 
metro network; prepare technical specifications for major equipment and review specifications 
for related items such as track, signal and telecom system; establish a structure gauge including 
the additional requirements for electric operation; establish the necessary safety guidelines and 
procedures for electric train operation; recommend suitable rolling stock design and fleet size 
considering future traffic growth; and recommend locations for the rolling stock maintenance 
plant and vehicle stabling areas, its capacity including individual workshops and general layout. 
 
11.  Social Development Expert (international, 2 person-months and national, 4 person-
months):  Prepare  (i)  poverty  and  social  analysis  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Handbook  on 
Poverty and Social Analysis: A Working Document (2012), (ii) indigenous peoples screening 
and impact categorization checklist, and (iii) indigenous peoples plan, if required, in accordance 
with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and other related policies such as the Public

4 
 
Communications Policy (2011), and (iii) initial gender analysis on proposed subprojects and 
identify adequate gender design measures. The scope shall include assessing labor standards, 
HIV, trafficking, and other social risks, as identified in the initial poverty and social assessment. 
12.  Resettlement Expert (international, 2 person-months and national, 4 person-months): 
(i) advise and collaborate with technical team during project selection and design to ensure 
resettlement impact is minimized or mitigated; (ii) prepare involuntary resettlement screening 
and impact categorization checklists; and (iii) prepare resettlement plans, resettlement and 
indigenous peoples framework or other relevant safeguard planning documents such as land 
acquisition due diligence reports in accordance with government regulations, ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009) and other related policies such as the ADB Public Communications 
Policy (2011). 
 
13.  Environment Expert (international, 3 person-months and national, 5 person-months): 
Prepare (i) environmental categorization form and rapid environmental assessment checklist; (ii) 
an environmental impact assessment in accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009) including climate change assessments; and (iii) an environmental assessment review 
framework. The scope of environmental due diligence will entail assessment of impacts due to 
metro  construction  including  related  facilities  such  as  stations,  power  supply  system,  and 
depots. The environmental analysis shall also include analysis of alternatives for depot sites. 
 
14.  Communication  Expert  (individual  consultant  assignment;  international,  3  person-
months):  Conduct  a  communication  assessment  (including  stakeholder  analysis)  and  use 
findings  to  prepare  a  communication  planning  roadmap  for  subsequent  stages  of  project 
preparation that will identify (i) communication activities that will be needed to support project 
preparation, especially safeguards and social development activities; (ii) further communication 
assessment activities that need to be completed in order to inform development of a full strategy 
for the projects engagement with stakeholder, project affected people, the public and media 
during project preparation, implementation and operation phases;  (iii) a draft communication 
strategy that will serve as a living document to be updated throughout project preparation as 
further assessment and planning activities are completed during later TAs for this project; and 
(iv) an assessment of the capacity of Dhaka Mass Transit company in terms of communication 
and recommendations for setting up and staffing the company's communication unit. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Dhaka Mass Transit Company Limited under the Ministry of Road Transport and 
Bridges will be the executing agency for the project.  
 
16.  All  disbursements  under  the TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended form time to time). All equipment 
procured under the TA will be disposed in line with ADB’s guidelines. 
 
17.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4.  
 
Table A3.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Major Milestones  Expected Completion Date 
Commencement  July 2016 
Physical completion  September 2017 
Financial closure  December 2017 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.
